docs.lead_paragraph: It is just past 7 on a Tuesday morning, and the nurses at Hlabisa Hospital are praying for deliverance. The stronger patients straighten their ailing bodies and chime in on wobbly legs. The bedridden croon through cracked lips. ''We are children of God,'' sing the nurses, clinging to their tattered hymnals in the dingy, overcrowded ward. ''We believe in the Lord. What we have in our hearts, heaven has put there.''

headline.main: A South African Hospital Fights AIDS and Despair

docs.abstract: Death and Denial, series on ravages of AIDS epidemic sweeping South Africa; focuses on community of Hlabisa in KwaZulu Natal Province, which has highest HIV infection rate in adults in South Africa; epidemic has swamped efforts of local hospital to cope with rising number of cases; there is shortage of staff and beds and general erosion of care as doctors and nurses struggle to conduct routine checks and tests; number of cases admitted has nearly doubled in last 10 years; none of infected patients have access to life-saving AIDS drugs available in West; workers are left questioning faith in medicine, their role as caretakers and future of community where parents can no longer assume their children will live beyond 35; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It is just past 7 on a Tuesday morning, and the nurses at Hlabisa Hospital are praying for deliverance. The stronger patients straighten their ailing bodies and chime in on wobbly legs. The bedridden croon through cracked lips.     ''We are children...

docs.lead_paragraph: The dusty road rolls past the builders hauling bricks from the Easi-Build Hardware store, past the women braiding hair at Ruby's Beauty Salon, past the butchers grinding beef at Isipho Supermarket, deep into the heart of rural South Africa. Change has come slowly to this remote community in Zululand. But there are water pumps in the green hills. Black tar smooths stretches of the mostly gravel road. Electric lights glimmer in mud huts. At Gwegwede Primary School, giddy adolescents dream aloud in a country that no longer stifles black ambition.

headline.main: South Africa's AIDS Vortex Engulfs a Rural Community

docs.abstract: First article in series, Death and Denial, about AIDS epidemic in South Africa; focuses on life in ravaged community of Hlabisa, poor Zulu area in KwaZulu Natal Province where third of adults are infected, or more than any other province in country, which has highest infection rate in world; it is one of few communities in South Africa in which government researchers have kept statistics on HIV infection rates for nearly decade, but also one where nation's culture of denial about disease is on full display; in past decade, number of patients admitted each year to public hospitals has nearly doubled; inadequate financing, shortage of health professionals and inept management have left hospitals desperate for doctors and nurses; yet many local high schools still fail to offer AIDS education programs, even though statistics show at least 25 percent of women under 20 are infected; even with some AIDS education efforts, there is scant evidence to suggest that many people are changing behavior; photos; maps (L)
docs.snippet: The dusty road rolls past the builders hauling bricks from the Easi-Build Hardware store, past the women braiding hair at Ruby's Beauty Salon, past the butchers grinding beef at Isipho Supermarket, deep into the heart of rural South Africa.    Change...

docs.lead_paragraph: Until the Dutch Experience cafe opened here earlier this fall, providing marijuana by the bag instead of beer by the pint, Stockport never loomed particularly large in the greater British imagination. ''I read in the newspaper that the only thing Stockport is famous for is the hat museum,'' said Darren Ince, 32, a retail manager, on his way to secure a joint or two at the cafe recently. ''I didn't know we were even famous for that.''

headline.main: English Pot Smokers' Pub May Prove a Model

docs.abstract: Dutch Experience cafe in northern English town of Stockport hosts marijuana smoking and could be thin end of wedge in Britain, where government is signaling it may ease laws on use of soft drugs in name of creating workable drug policy; photos; government says police spend inordinate amount of time dealing with minor drug offenses, with 65 percent of 120,000 drug-related arrests last year for marijuana possession; Stockport police raided cafe day it opened in September but did not act again until cafe began attracting publicity (M)
docs.snippet: Until the Dutch Experience cafe opened here earlier this fall, providing marijuana by the bag instead of beer by the pint, Stockport never loomed particularly large in the greater British imagination.    ''I read in the newspaper that the only thing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Middle-age and elderly people who took anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen or naproxen for at least two years were apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease, according to a new study by scientists in the Netherlands. Their likelihood of getting Alzheimer's dementia was one-sixth that of people who did not take the drugs. The study, published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, offers hope for preventing Alzheimer's but falls short of being definitive, experts said. They cautioned that the findings did not mean that people should dose themselves with anti-inflammatories, which can have serious side effects, to prevent Alzheimer's.

headline.main: Hints of an Alzheimer's Aid In Anti-Inflammatory Drugs

docs.abstract: Dutch study finds that middle-aged and elderly people taking anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen or naproxen, for at least two years are apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease; group's likelihood of getting Alzheimer's was one-sixth that of people not taking these drugs, mostly for arthritis; caution on study's limitations noted (S)
